Answers. Best Answer: Interphase is the longest phase of the cell cycle because it can be thought of as the most active phase. A cell spends most of its life in interphase; during this phase, a cell grows, makes ATP and organelles, copies chromosomes, makes microfilaments, prepares for mitosis, etc. Basically, most of the stuff a cell does in its life is during interphase. It's why so much time is consumed during it. Source(s):

Best Answer: Because cells have to grow, and get energy before they can divide. Interphase is the phase in the cell cycle which would be pretty much the normal activity of the cell. The cell grows during interphase and carries on its normal activities. Many cells never divide and their entire lives are spent in interphase. The duration of time spent in interphase and in each stage of interphase is variable and depends on both the type of cell and the species of organism it belongs to. Most cells of adult mammals spend about 20 hours in interphase; this accounts for about 90% of the total time involved in cell division. Interphase is the 'daily living' or metabolic phase of the cell, in which the cell obtains nutrients and metabolizes them, grows, reads its DNA, and conducts other normal cell functions. The majority of eukaryotic cells spend most of their time in interphase. This phase was formerly called the resting phase

Cell CycleThe cell cycle is the life-cycle of the cell. Cells in multicellular animals, like humans, cycle between two phases: interphase (I phase), the interval between mitosis, and mitosis (M phase) itself (including nuclear division and cell division). Most cells are in interphase most of the time.
